en: Letter from C. D. Snead to Professor L. L. McInnis of Texas A&M College dated November 9, 1881, presenting a third mathematical solution to a geometric problem involving the division of a trapezoid into two equal parts by a line parallel to the base. Snead submits his geometric principles for McInnis's review and verification, demonstrating the application of proportional reasoning and triangulation methods to solve the problem, with calculations and a marginal diagram included.

ALBERT MANTOOTH, President,
C. N. SNEED, Secretary.

J. D. GANN, Cor. Secretary.
OFFICE OF

JOSEPH KERR, Vice-President.
C. MANTOOTH, Treasurer.

ANGELINA CO. IMMIGRATION SOCIETY.

Homer, Texas, Nov 9" 1881

Prof. L. L. McInnis
Prof. Math. A & M College
Dear Sir

I am thankful to
you for the plain and accurate solutions of our
problem. A gentleman here stated that it
was a mathematical impossibility, and
a mathematical absurdity. I here submit
a third solution for your approval, and if
you find my principles correct, please so
state it to me.

To divide the trapezoid ABCD into two equal
parts by a line parallel to the base DC.
DC = 12, DH = 6c HC = 6 chs AB = 4 chs
HG = 24 chs. Produce AD to I & BC
to I forming the triangle ICD. Pro-
duce GH to I, also. My object is to
find GI and then apply the prin-
ciples for cutting triangles.

DC - AB : AB :: HG : GI
8 : 4 :: 24 : 12
Then HI = 36, Now we have to find IC
√(HC)² + (HI)² = IC
√36 + 1296 = √1332 = 36.496

(Area ICD = 216 chs)
over

[Diagram in right margin showing triangle ICD with bisecting line AB. Labels and measurements:
Top vertex: I
Left side segment: 12.165
Right side segments: 12.165, 36.496
Base AB: 4 chs
Base DC: 12 chs (split into 6 chs, H, 6 chs)
Central height HG: 24 chs]
